;周五，在与乌克兰接壤的俄罗斯别尔哥罗德地区的炮击中，两名平民丧生，而莫斯科军队连续第六天袭击了基辅。

;

;过去几天，随着别尔哥罗德西南部地区的炮击加剧，数百名居民逃离了俄罗斯与乌克兰边境附近的村庄。

;

;记者说，来自 Shebekino 镇的居民一直涌入该地区的主要城市别尔哥罗德，周五那里的气氛平静。体育场 - 已成为该市最大的流离失所者中心 - 看起来拥挤但干净。

;

;志愿者分发白色手镯，让人们获得免费餐点，并组织他们转移到较小的宿舍。十几个人挤在电视机前，有些人在观看 Shebekino 的新闻发展时情绪激动。

;

;别尔哥罗德州州长 Vyacheslav Gladkov 说，有 2,500 人被安置在临时避难所，包括体育场馆。

;

; p>;

;当天早些时候，地区长官说有两名妇女被炮击炸死。

;

;“弹片击中了路过的汽车。两名乘坐其中一辆车的妇女因伤当场死亡，”他说。

;

;Shebekino 地区的一个村庄遭到炮击，两人受重伤。该地区负责人弗拉基米尔日丹诺夫 (Vladimir Zhdanov) 表示，当局正在继续疏散人员，但面临困难条件。

;

;周四，俄罗斯国防部表示，部队使用喷气式飞机和大炮击退了乌克兰“入侵”的企图”别尔哥罗德地区。

;

;军方表示，此次袭击“涉及多达 70 名武装分子、5 辆坦克、4 辆装甲车、7 辆皮卡和一辆卡玛斯卡车”。

;

;另外周五，乌克兰 Zaporizhia 地区的 Komyshevaha 村遭到炮击，造成 2 人死亡，4 人受伤。

;

;Yuriy Malashko 在 Telegram 消息应用程序上说，俄罗斯军队击中了乌克兰东南部靠近前线的小村庄的多层住宅楼。

;

;随着与乌克兰边境的暴力事件升级，克里姆林宫谴责国际社会的沉默，尽管“有机会看到描述对住宅建筑和社会基础设施的袭击的镜头。”

;

;美国已表示不支持在俄罗斯境内发动袭击，而是向基辅提供设备和培训以自卫。

;

;乌克兰的防空得到了西方装备的支持，包括爱国者防空系统，该系统被视为美国最先进的防空系统之一。

;

;乌克兰首都在 5 月几乎每晚都遭遇空袭，此前相对今年年初幸免于难。

;

;周五，乌克兰表示，它已经摧毁了新一波夜间袭击造成基辅两人受伤的所有 15 枚导弹和 21 架无人机。

;

;“在过去的六天里，[俄罗斯人]已经对这座城市进行了六次袭击！”首都城市管理局局长谢尔盖·波普科 (Sergiy Popko) 在电报中表示。

;

;俄罗斯国防部表示，部队袭击了乌克兰保护“关键”军事基础设施的防空系统，并且“所有指定目标都已被击中”。

;

;在远离西方支持的国家东部和南部前线的基辅加强打击，引发了人们对俄罗斯精打细算的质疑。

;

;一些专家表示，克里姆林宫可能会俄罗斯试图阻止乌克兰计划中的反攻并削弱其防空力量。

;

;周四，俄罗斯用弹道导弹和导弹袭击基辅时，火箭弹碎片落下，导致三人在基辅丧生，其中包括一名 9 岁儿童。

;

;其中一名受害者 Yaroslav Ryabchuk 的丈夫说，他们经常躲避俄罗斯袭击的避难所已经关闭。在最近的悲剧发生后，乌克兰总统 Volodymyr Zelensky 表示必须检查基辅的所有避难所。

;

;他发誓要追究所有责任人的责任，他说“可能会被淘汰”，显然是一个薄薄的 -前拳击手基辅市长维塔利·克里琴科 (Vitali Klitschko) 发出含蓄警告。

;

;克里琴科说，已采取措施确保“全天候进入避难所”。

;

;“敌人是现在正在用弹道导弹炮击首都，”克里琴科告诉居民，说他们可能只有“几分钟”的时间躲起来。

;

;他建议居民躲在家里，用两堵墙从外面保护起来，“如果你明白你不会那么快到达避难所”。

;

;俄罗斯国防部周五表示，车臣特种部队“Akhmat”小组正在马林卡镇附近发动攻势，在乌克兰东部的顿涅茨克地区。

;

;与叶夫根尼·普里戈任领导的瓦格纳雇佣军一起，来自俄罗斯车臣共和国的军队一直是莫斯科在乌克兰发动攻势的主要推动力之一。

;< p>;Akhmat 指挥官 Apti Alaudinov 周四表示，他的部队正被转移到“另一个地区”以准备反攻，但没有说明部队的位置或去向。

;

;与 Prigozhin 不同，车臣领导人拉姆赞·卡德罗夫 (Ramzan Kadyrov) 曾多次抨击俄罗斯的军事领导层，但最近却没有回应对国防部的批评。

;

;此后，这两个组织的成员公开争吵，卡德罗夫的一位亲密盟友周四将普里戈任(Prigozhin)作为一个总是对问题大喊大叫的博主。

;华盛顿正在制定新法规，限制资本和信息流入敏感技术根据一位美国财政部官员的评论，中国如芯片和人工智能 (AI) 受到了北京的谴责，分析师也警告称流向中国初创企业的资本正在减少。

;

;这些计划，参考周三，负责投资安全的财政部助理部长保罗·罗森 (Paul Rosen) 表示，这将使华盛顿能够更大程度地控制在特定行业和子行业（例如先进半导体）中转移“具有专门知识和专业知识的美国投资资金” 、人工智能和量子计算。

;

;中国外交部发言人毛宁周四坚决反对这一消息，称美国正在“将贸易和科技问题政治化和武器化”，为正常的技术合作制造障碍并破坏

;

;“这种做法是有害的，不符合任何人的利益，”她补充说。

;

;在中国芯片公司工作的美国公民陷入科技战

;

;人工智能、量子计算和负责为这些技术提供必要计算能力的半导体已成为美国和中国之间日益增长的争论点，因为它们被认为有可能影响国家安全。罗森说，限制的目的是防止中国获得可用于增强军事或情报能力的资源。

;

;这与之前的报道相呼应，即拜登政府正在努力敲定一项行政命令，计划于今年夏天，限制对中国高科技产业的某些境外投资。北京发言人在 4 月份承认了这些报道，称他们将密切关注事态发展并强烈反对此类政策。

;

;因此，分析师表示，中国科技初创企业的资金将继续枯竭。

;

; p>;

;香港 Kaiyuan Capital 首席投资官 Brock Silvers 表示，“几乎可以肯定的结果是，如果政府继续实施此类限制措施并且贸易紧张局势继续升级，美国将减少对中国科技公司的资助”。< /p>;

;此举正值中国科技公司的资金枯竭之际。据路透社报道，根据研究公司 Preqin 的数据，以中国为重点的风险投资筹资活动将迎来至少八年来最疲软的上半年。

;

;“在美国方面，具有全球影响力的风险投资，尤其是资本市场研究公司 PitchBook Data 的风险投资分析师 Kaidi Gao 表示：“那些在中国设有办事处的公司已经开始重新评估他们的中国战略。”

;

;随着外国资金从美国流入的速度放缓，一些中国人她补充说，资产管理公司将被迫更加重视从美国以外地区（例如东南亚）筹集资金。

;

;与此同时，中国和美国都在加大对人工智能武器的国家投资种族。根据 PitchBook 的一份报告，美国国防部在人工智能方面的总支出预计到 2024 年将达到 18 亿美元，这是受到与中国等地缘政治对手的战略竞争的刺激。 2022 年，国防部向 AI 供应商授予了 79 份合同。

;

;北京政府已招募中国主要科技公司加快自身 AI 发展，国家对该行业的投资预计将达到 266.9 亿美元2026年，政府还严厉打击第三方应用程序使用ChatGPT等海外生成人工智能产品，其美国开发商OpenAI尚未在国内正式上市。

;

;针对Silver 表示，随着最新的资本限制，中国和美国都有望解决其国内的脆弱性。 “因此，中国将继续努力发展更强大的芯片专业知识，而美国将开始回流其关键矿产供应链，”他说。

; Fri, 02 Jun 2023 22:50:03 +0800 Big powers must avoid ‘diplomatic deep freezes’ for stable world order: Australia’s Albanesehttps://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3222816/big-powers-must-avoid-diplomatic-deep-freezes-stable-world-order-australias-albanese?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.02 22:30;
;;

;亚太地区乃至世界的稳定与安全唯有保障澳大利亚总理安东尼·艾博年 (Anthony Albanese) 周五表示，通过所有国家的集体责任，任何大国的“外交深度冻结”都会引起误解和猜疑。

;

;在香格里拉峰会上发表主旨演讲在新加坡的对话中，Albanese 表示，和平、稳定和安全不能被视为理所当然，并警告说，任何国家都不能认为自己可以凌驾于多边规则之上。

;

;为了共同负责，所有国家都必须始终参与，保持公开对话和外交——即建立护栏，让所有国家遵守商定的多边规则。

;

;澳大利亚可以在美中紧张局势中发挥亚洲“稳定作用”：新加坡

;

;Albanese 说，当任何国家认为自己凌驾于这些规则之上时，稳定就会崩溃，并指出《联合国海洋法公约》对该地区的重要性。

;

;“澳大利亚的目标不是为战争做准备，而是通过威慑和保证以及在该地区建立复原力来预防战争，尽我们的一份力量来履行我们所有人维护和平与安全的共同责任，”他说。

;< p>;“并明确表示，当涉及到任何单方面试图通过武力改变现状时，无论是台湾、南中国海、东中国海还是其他地方，冲突的风险永远远远大于任何潜在的冲突

;

;在全球范围内，Albanese 表示，自由贸易和全球化将支持稳定的世界秩序的自满情绪似乎正在消退，各国现在意识到他们没有“对多边机制的维护和有效性给予足够的重视”机构和全球规则”。

;

;为了做得更好，大国和国家必须建立最基本的护栏，即摆脱“外交深度冻结”，Albanese 说。

;

;“外交深度冻结的沉默只会滋生猜疑，只会让各国更容易将动机归因于误解，互相假设最坏的情况，”他说。

;

;“如果你不这样做有对话的压力阀，如果你没有能力——在决策层面——拿起电话，寻求一些清晰度或提供一些背景，那么假设溢出的风险总是更大陷入无法挽回的行动和反应。”

;

;澳大利亚“充满希望”的大麦对中国的出口将在两国关系升温的情况下很快恢复

;

;为此，澳大利亚已采取行动通过稳定其关系来树立榜样Albanese 说，尽管仍然存在挑战，但 Albanese 表示，堪培拉已经试图认识到，“如果我们直接交易，总是更好，总是更有效”，而不管两国政府之间的分歧。

;

;“中国非凡的经济转型不仅造福于其本国人民，也造福于我们整个地区，”Albanese 说。

;

;这位澳大利亚领导人还表达了对潜在不稳定因素的担忧他的国家通过安全联盟 Aukus 购买核动力潜艇引发了这一事件。

;

;这些期望......[成为]一个更强大的合作伙伴和更有效地促进我们地区稳定的贡献者，”Albanese 说，并补充说 Aukus 是关于伙伴关系，而不是竞争。

;

;早些时候在新加坡举行的新闻发布会上Albanese 在与城市国家副总理 Lawrence Wong 举行第八届澳大利亚-新加坡年度领导人会议时表示，他的政府亲自致电 60 多个国家，以提供 Aukus 的透明度。

;

;除了 Albanese 与新加坡政府的会晤之外在对话中，澳大利亚国防部长 Wong 还会见了来自斐济和乌克兰的国防部长。

;

;对于新加坡，Albanese 同意支持多边合作，正如他在演讲中所指出的那样，并保持东盟的中心地位。

;

;Albanese 和 Wong 还联合发起了一项耗资 2000 万澳元（1320 万美元）的 Go-Green 联合创新计划，提供为期四年的赠款，以推动新加坡和澳大利亚之间的联合创新。他们还同意在 2025 年底之前建立一条绿色和数字航运走廊，以帮助港口和航运业实现脱碳和数字化。

;

;澳大利亚承诺成为新加坡可靠的能源供应商，包括天然气以满足全球排放目标。倒塌的 Sun Cable 项目将太阳能发电从澳大利亚北领地传输到新加坡，最近恢复了运行。

;

;香格里拉对话已进入第 20 届，也是时隔两年后的第二次会议到大流行。来自40多个国家的部长出席会议，其中部长级代表48人，国防高官35余人。

;三名香港男子被判入狱长达五年零两个月因警察在 2019 年反政府抗议活动高峰期围攻一所大学而引发骚乱。

;

;周五在西九龙法院因大规模骚乱而被判刑的四名被告之一2019 年 11 月 18 日，警察在靠近理工大学的油麻地路口围捕了 200 多名抗议者。

;

;27 岁的李永贤在法院驳回他的判决后被判处最重刑期 62 个月声称他在对峙期间是一名摄影记者。

;

;24 岁的 Yu Pak-hang 被判入狱 57 个月，23 岁的 Chen Zhiyuan 被判入狱 4.5 年。

;< p>;学生邓妙秀，19 岁，因当时年仅 16 岁，被判入教所最长三年拘禁。

;

;区域法院暂委法官严舜仪收留少年在还押期间表现出真诚的悔意，向她提供的职业和品格发展培训将帮助她翻过这一页。

;

;但 Yim 说，这三名男子应该受到威慑性的判决，因为他们涉及严重的罪行，危及公共安全。

;

;大都会大学毕业生李在今年早些时候的审判中说，他是一名摄影记者，并出示了一张记者证和一件反光背心作为他角色的证据。

;

;但 Yim 在上个月的判决中驳回了他的论点，并表示 Lee 未能提交任何证据证明他当天拍摄的照片已被发表。

;

;她补充说，她也无法找到记者为什么会这样做的理由将背心系在腰间而不是穿它以表明身份。

;

;13 人因理大附近的“迷你战区”骚乱而入狱

;

;在另一起案件中，五男两女承认在同一场油麻地抗议活动中发生骚乱。

;

;在区域法院出庭的七人是 23 岁的学生胡海威、21 岁​​的 Reaf Yeun Wing-sing 和 Chester Wan Yuk-yin , 26;职员徐鹏义，30岁；装修工人叶颖珊，24岁； 23 岁的兼职女服务员张紫晴和 30 岁的编辑周凤燕。

;

;法官陈广智在本月晚些时候将被告还押候审。

;

;在长达数月的骚乱中，这所大学发生了一些最严重的暴力事件，抗议者占领了这所大学，并在校园内设置路障，以防防暴警察试图逮捕他们。

;

;支持者在大学周边地区举行了多次抗议活动校园，目的是让被困在大学校园内的人有机会逃生。

;

;3 名急救志愿者因香港理工大学附近的骚乱被判入狱长达 19 个月

;

;警方逮捕了 213 人11 月 18 日晚上的抗议活动期间，他们在油麻地地铁站附近。

;

;他们被拘留了两天，然后被带到全市六个裁判法院，面临暴动指控。

;

;这是历次因同一罪名被告人最多的一次。

;

;213人被分成17组受审。到目前为止，共有 110 人被定罪。

;

;两人在审判后被宣告无罪，三人潜逃。

;

;早些时候判处的刑期从 29 到 64 个月不等，再到在培训中心拘留。

;沙特、伊朗等十多个国家的高官就近周五与主要新兴经济体的金砖国家集团举行会议，以加深联系并将自己定位为抗衡西方的力量。

;

;金砖国家，现在由巴西、俄罗斯、印度、中国和南非组成金砖国家正在考虑扩大其成员数量，越来越多的国家（主要来自南半球）表示有兴趣加入。

;

;曾被视为不同新兴经济体的松散联盟，金砖国家近年来采取了更具体的形状，最初由中国推动，自 2022 年 2 月乌克兰战争开始以来，俄罗斯又增加了推动力。

;

;东道主南非外交部长纳莱迪潘多尔在周五的讨论开幕式上谈到了该集团作为发展中国家的拥护者，她说在 Covid-19 大流行期间被富裕国家和全球机构抛弃了。

;

;“世界的合作步履蹒跚。发达国家从未履行过对发展中国家的承诺，并试图将所有责任转移到全球南方，”Pandor 说。

;

;在普京可能访问之前，南非在退出国际刑事法院方面退缩

;

;官方节目显示，伊朗、沙特阿拉伯、阿拉伯联合酋长国、古巴、刚果民主共和国、科摩罗、加蓬和哈萨克斯坦都派代表前往开普敦进行所谓的“金砖国家之友”会谈。

;

;埃及、阿根廷、孟加拉国、几内亚比绍和印度尼西亚以虚拟方式参与。

;

;金砖五国的重量级国家中国去年表示，它希望该集团启动接纳新成员的程序。其他成员指出了他们希望看到加入该俱乐部的国家/地区。

;

;但是，官员们周四表示仍有工作要做，并且似乎注意到需要谨慎行事。

;

;“金砖国家是成功的历史”，巴西外长毛罗·维埃拉说。 “该集团也是一个品牌和资产，因此我们必须照顾好它。”

;

;印度外交部长 Subrahmanyam Jaishankar 表示，周四的会谈包括对指导原则、标准、标准和程序的审议扩大后的金砖国家集团会是什么样子。

;

;“这仍在进行中，”他补充说。

;

;印度外交部此前曾强调需要为这样一个国家制定共同政策

;

;南非的潘多尔表示，各国外交部长的目标是在金砖国家领导人 8 月于约翰内斯堡举行的峰会之前完成接纳新成员的框架工作.

;

;由于俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京 (Vladimir Putin) 可能出席，他是国际刑事法院 (ICC) 发出的逮捕令的目标，因此峰会的筹备工作在充满争议的气氛中继续进行。

; Fri, 02 Jun 2023 21:50:03 +0800 China Telecom plans huge computing centre in Shanghai’s hi-tech zone, helping to build computational power to support AI drivehttps://www.scmp.com/tech/big-tech/article/3222796/china-telecom-plans-huge-computing-centre-shanghais-hi-tech-zone-helping-build-computational-power?utm_source=rss_feed

;China Telecom, which is quickly emerging as a powerful player in China's cloud market, has unveiled a plan to set up a huge computing centre in the hi-tech zone of Shanghai to support the city's artificial intelligence (AI) industry.

;

;The state-owned company, through a subsidiary, plans to deploy a total of 40,000 high-power racks – each rack usually contains dozens of servers – for intelligent computing and supercomputing. The company did not disclose the investment size. China had 6.5 million racks in total as of the end of 2022.

;

;It marks one of the biggest investments by China Telecom in computing centres as China accelerates development of its national computational power capabilities. This comes amid increased rivalry in advanced technologies, such as AI, with the US.

;

;The development of AI technology, especially evident in the recent frenzy around ChatGPT-like services, is fuelling demand for the computing power needed by large language models (LLM).

;

;C2NET admits first provinces in its drive to pool national computing power

;

;The computing centre in Shanghai's Lingang New Area will mainly serve local development of graphics processing units (GPUs) as the world's dominant GPU maker, Nvidia, is not allowed to sell its most advanced products to China. The home-grown GPUs, in turn, can help AI businesses in Shanghai and the Yangtze River Delta, the official Shanghai Securities News reported.

;

;China is pulling together resources from the state and corporate sector to seek technology breakthroughs in its whole-country approach, although the jury is still out on whether the approach will work.

;

;Separately, an association called Lingang New Area Intelligent Computing Industry Alliance, which aims to “share computing power resources, technologies and foster cooperation” among members, was created on Friday in Lingang led by China Unicom, another major state-owned telecoms network operator.

;

;As a number of Chinese Big Tech companies, including Baidu, Alibaba Group Holding and many others have jumped on the generative AI bandwagon by launching their own LLMs, concerns are also rising that China is facing mounting pressure in terms of access to computing power. Alibaba owns the Post.

;

;Last August the US banned Nvidia from selling its high-performance A100 and H100 data centre GPUs to China-based customers without a licence, as part of a larger US-led effort to reduce China's access to advanced chips.

;

;Lingang New Area, part of Shanghai's free-trade zone developed at the direction of President Xi Jinping in 2019, can be seen as China's response when it comes to expanding computing capacity, envisioned by Shanghai's authorities as an important gathering place for the national AI industry.

;

;At an industry conference held in Lingang this February, local officials renewed their pledge to attract 20,000 to 30,000 workers to AI and 500 related enterprises to the area by 2025. SenseTime, one of China's leading AI companies, opened up an AI data centre in the area last January, the largest facility of its kind in Asia.

;

;By 2025, a “multi-computing power supply system” will be formed in the area, led by intelligent computing power, with a total industry scale exceeding 10 billion yuan, Wu Xiaohua, deputy Communist Party secretary of Lingang, said at the conference on Friday.

;

;State-owned telecoms network operators have emerged as a key part of the jigsaw in providing computing power for AI development in Shanghai and neighbouring areas, as the city doubles down on efforts to become a national AI hub.

;China is “trying its best” to mediate in the war in Ukraine but it should not overplay its role and exercise “unreasonable power” on Kyiv, British defence secretary Ben Wallace said on Friday.

;

;On Britain's role, he said it would do “everything we can in our power” to help if Ukraine decided to hammer out a peace deal with Russia.

;

;“We will always stand by to help with peace. But fundamentally, that peace has to be where Ukraine chooses as a sovereign country to seek peace,” he said in an interview with This Week In Asia on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore on Friday. “It is their country that has been invaded and not anybody else's.”

;

;Last month, Wallace travelled to Kyiv where he met his Ukrainian counterpart Oleksii Reznikov as Britain boosted military support for Ukraine, including the provision of the Storm Shadow long-range cruise missiles.

;

;China, meanwhile, has sought to offer itself as a neutral party while playing the role of mediator, most recently sending a special envoy to both Ukraine and Russia.

;

;The British defence chief said that China had recognised that instability caused by the war was not good for the world and the global economic environment, and that he welcomed Beijing's efforts.

;

;“But our position has always been, it is for Ukraine to decide when it wants to negotiate and it must be able to negotiate from a position of strength, not from a position of a sort of intimidation and weakness caused by Russians activity,” he said.

;

;“China ... trying its best, that's great. As long as it doesn't use that unreasonably to try and put unreasonable power on Ukraine … it cannot be at the expense of the Ukrainians.”

;

;Wallace confirmed during the interview that he would meet his Chinese counterpart Li Shangfu on the sidelines of the security conference in Singapore on Saturday.

;

;On concerns among some Indo-Pacific nations that the West would pay less attention to the region as countries pledged greater military support to Ukraine, Wallace insisted this was not the case.

;

;He noted that European nations had increased their defence spending as a whole.

;

;“I don't think we're going to see less. We're going to see more and how those countries use that [budget hike], we'll be able to involve supporting our friends and allies in the Pacific,” he said. “There will be plenty to go around.”

;

;Taiwan the 'most dangerous flashpoint' in US-China rivalry, Singapore PM says

;

;Wallace was also asked about tensions between China and the self-ruled island Taiwan, which Beijing regards as a renegade province. The defence secretary stressed that any resolution had to be peaceful and without the use of force or coercion.

;

;He would only say that all countries – including Britain, the United States, and China – did not want a conflict and that Britain and its allies were “working to make sure there is a peaceful resolution”.

;

;“Resolving the issue in a peaceful manner is absolutely at the top of the agenda,” he said.

;

;In the wide-ranging interview, Wallace also warned about China's military build-up, saying that it was a “threat to the rule of law”.

;

;Britain's foreign secretary James Cleverly had in April urged China to be more transparent about its military expansion, which he described as the “biggest military build-up in peacetime history”.

;

;Wallace on Friday drew parallels to Russia's actions in Ukraine, describing it as “ripping up the rule book”, saying it sent a signal to the world that the rule of law did not matter any more – something countries should be concerned about.

;

;Particularly, he stressed that disputes between China and several Southeast Asian nations in the South China Sea was an issue that “can't be dealt with by someone just using their scale or brute force”.

;

;Southeast Asian countries had been “doing the right things” to voice their concerns over China's aggression in the region while partnering with other nations – including Britain – who shared the same values.

;

;“We're not here to provoke. We are here to say that stability is what leads to all our empowerment and enrichment,” he said.

; Fri, 02 Jun 2023 21:20:03 +0800 Chinese, US defence chiefs are in Singapore for Shangri-La Dialogue, but will bilateral talks happen?https://www.scmp.com/news/china/military/article/3222807/chinese-us-defence-chiefs-are-singapore-shangri-la-dialogue-will-bilateral-talks-happen?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.02 21:13;
;;

;The defence ministers of both China and the United States have kicked off separate efforts to vie for support from Asia-Pacific nations at the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore, but chances of a much-needed meeting between the two remain slim.

;

;Chinese defence chief General Li Shangfu on Friday led officers of the People's Liberation Army (PLA) for closed-door bilateral meetings with officials from Mongolia, New Zealand, the Philippines and Cambodia.

;

;The meetings came as the coastguards of the US, Japan and the Philippines carried out joint maritime exercises in the South China Sea. The week-long drills launched on Thursday is their first such trilateral exercise amid growing concerns about China's maritime expansion in the region.

;

;The joint exercises in waters off the Philippine province of Bataan will include counter-piracy simulations, and possibly an interception exercise involving a vessel carrying weapons of mass destruction, Philippine coastguard spokesman Armand Balilo said earlier this week.

;

;Balilo said Japan and the US had approached his country in February, the same month that Enrique Manalo, the Philippine foreign minister, confirmed regular cases of “harassment” in the contested South China Sea.

;

;Manalo's accusation at the Munich Security Forum came after a Chinese navy ship and dozens of Chinese militia vessels surrounded the Philippine-controlled Thitu island in the disputed Spratly archipelago also claimed by Beijing.

;

;Meanwhile, there was still little hope of a meeting between Li and US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin in Singapore, after the US said China had declined a proposal for talks at the major annual Asia-Pacific security conference.

;

;China says US must correct 'mistaken actions' before top defence chiefs meet

;

;Chinese Lieutenant General He Lei told the Post that the PLA on May 29 “formally rejected” a request by Austin for a face-to-face meeting with Li on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue.

;

;“I am afraid that it's the first time China has used the word 'reject' in its military-to-military diplomacy with the US,” said He, who is a former deputy director of the PLA Academy of Military Science and among the delegates accompanying Li.

;

;Washington's refusal to lift the sanctions on Li was one of the key reasons for rejecting the request, he added.

;

;“The sanctions on Li target not only Li himself, but also the PLA, as such a move is aimed at restricting China's defence development and military modernisation.”

;

;The US imposed secondary sanctions in 2018 on Li and the equipment department of the top Chinese military decision-making body, for helping China to buy Su-35 fighter jets and hardware related to the S-400 missile system from Rosoboronexport, Russia's main state arms exporter.

;

;Rosoboronexport had earlier attracted US sanctions because it violated American law restricting weapons trade with Iran, North Korea and Syria.

;

;The sanctions do not bar Li from meeting Austin.

;

;“However, China never shuts the door to communication between the two militaries. It will be ready to talk once it feels the timing is good, and it should be the Chinese military that takes the initiative, not the Americans,” He said.

;

;The US earlier said it was worried that China was not interested in defence dialogue.

;

;On Friday morning, Austin and his Singaporean counterpart Ng Eng Hen held a bilateral meeting to discuss defence cooperation and geopolitical developments in the Asia-Pacific, a Singapore defence ministry statement said.

;

;Next, Austin met his counterparts from the 10 member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean), which includes Singapore, to discuss US initiatives to maintain a “rules-based regional security environment”, the ministry said.

;

;The Pentagon chief then met Indonesian Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto in an unofficial two-way meeting.

;

;The US has multiple initiatives to strengthen ties with Asia-Pacific countries, ranging from economic to military, and to promote a democratic international order. Such diplomatic outreach has irritated the Chinese government, which criticised them as dividing the region and aiming to contain China.

;

;On Friday, Chinese defence chief Li also “exchanged views on global and regional security developments” with Singapore's acting prime minister Lawrence Wong, who is widely expected to be city-state's next leader, the Singapore's defence ministry said in a statement without elaborating.

;

;The Chinese delegation, led by Li, will hold more two-way meetings between defence ministers on the second of three days of the Shangri-La Dialogue.

;

;British Defence Secretary Ben Wallace would meet Li on Saturday, he told the South China Morning Post.

;

;US-China rivalry and how Asia-Pacific and European countries are expected to loom over most of the Shangri-La Dialogue.

;

;US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin is scheduled to speak on Saturday about American “leadership in the Indo-Pacific”, followed by a speech on Sunday by Li about China's security initiatives.

;

;In advance of speeches by the defence chiefs at the Shangri-La Dialogue, Chinese state media has played up Chinese President Xi Jinping's signature Global Security Initiative, a wide-ranging set of policy directions on China's perspective on the world order.

;

;The basket of principles includes opposition to unilateral sanctions, non-interventionism and an emphasis on dialogue to resolve disputes, which are reflected in Beijing's position on the Ukraine war.

;

;India's foreign ministry said on Friday it hoped Beijing would allow Indian journalists to continue to work in China, and said that New Delhi allows all foreign journalists to operate in India.

;

;The Indian statement came two days after China said it had taken “appropriate” action in response to India's treatment of Chinese journalists.

;

;India and China, whose relations have nosedived since a deadly military clash on their Himalayan border in 2020, have been involved in a row over visas for each other's journalists.

;

;It began in April after two Indian journalists posted in Beijing were barred from returning to their jobs in the Chinese capital from India.

;

;China had at that time said the action was a “corresponding countermeasure” to India's treatment of Chinese journalists.

;

;China vows to take countermeasures against India over journalist visas

;

;The friction resurfaced this week after Beijing refused to renew the visa of one of the two remaining Indian journalists in China.

;

;Beijing said this was in response to India this month declining to renew the visas of the last two Chinese state media journalists in India.

;

;“All foreign journalists, including Chinese journalists, have been pursuing journalistic activities in India without any limitations or difficulties in reporting or doing media coverage,” Indian foreign ministry spokesperson Arindam Bagchi said.

;

;At the same time, he said, there should be no deviations from “normal journalistic behaviour and activities, or from the provisions governing Journalist visas”.

;

;“Meanwhile, Indian journalists in China have been operating with certain difficulties, such as not being permitted to hire locals as correspondents or journalists,” Bagchi said.

;

;They also faced restrictions while getting access and travelling locally, Bagchi said.

;

;“We hope that Chinese authorities facilitate the continued presence of Indian journalists working and reporting from China,” he said.

;

;While military tensions between the neighbours have eased since the May 2020 violence in which 24 soldiers were killed, diplomatic ties remain strained.

;

;Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi last month said peace on the border was essential for normal relations with China and their ties can only be based on mutual respect, sensitivity and interest.
